text: Plenty of baby formula, baby food, wipes,cases of water. If you or anyone else in need contact me.

I live at (next to Equestrian Center) & the subdivisions south of me (Kelliwood Terrace) & across Mason Rd to the west (N Lake Village?) are now under mandatory evacuation orders. My complex entrance is at Mason & Northmoor. Do I need to worry about my complex flooding and if not...is the possibility of Mason flooding a real concern? I don't want to get stuck and not be able to leave even if I don't flood. Thanks. 48 Fire Department...thank you. The new map shows Northmoor and Mason

Fire Department...thank you. The new map shows Northmoor and Mason in the red zone. That is the entrance to my community. Please do what you feel is the safest for your family. If you want to evacuate and can do so safely, then please do so. Fire Department...thank you. Yes.I want to do that but do it educated. FBCOEM says evacuate and then the Corp of Engineers say no new structural flooding. Those pieces of info conflict. Thanks again

Thank you for all your help. Thank you for the update! Thank you all for everything Sorry if someone asked and you have answered this question. Is Memorial Parkway area ok or should we be ready to leave the area? Thanks! Memorial Parkway is not in the danger zone

After five days of sleepless night and long, hard days my family is safe and dry and our amazing community has come together to help families who were impacted by what history will likely call the worst hurricane in the history of our nation. Hurricane Harvev

Folks- an important update. The official post is coming from Ok Folks- I just spoke to their Public Communications Officer. And again, seems there's more "misinformation" out about the new so called list of neighborhoods that may flood. He said that no one has added anything. "That list is just a compilation of subdivisions that exist in the Barker water shed but has nothing to with water levels or evacuation areas. No one is adding anything. They grabbed an old list that had 9 neighborhoods that don't exist and missed 6 that do." That said, be vigilant. Evacuate if you can to higher ground. Consider going to Friends not affected by the Barker. I know it's hard. We are on plan e and f ourselves, but we will get through this and get back to our amazing neighborhood. I'll continue to share as I can. with ESD 48. He's have been attached to an FD. Thanks tor evervone's help!
Now maybe people will believe me. Thank you! Can you make this shareable? done! And ESD 48 will pay a Update soon. You're awesome! And truly, THANK YOU for sharing this
Thank you relaxed. feel a little more Thanks for the updates -keep them coming we have left the house at the moment. Stay safe x Thank you! does this apply to you?

I I nave received a water level alert since 10:15. I saw a rumor that the guage was broken. Do you know anything? Which website. I couldn't find it. Do they indicate if they can repair and when? Yes the gauge is broken. They will attempt to install a tempory gauge today. It is at 100 feet right now (said at 8am press conference) The gauge failed but the current level as of 5pm was 101.4 feet.

I saw on the news last night that a lot of the gauges are gone across all of Houston due to the unprecedented amount of water. They said if they don't have a recent update and show old data then the gauge is likely gone. Where is the official post from We have been holding our post to get the latest data from the Army Corp of Engineers. I will be posting it shortly. Here is our update:

URGENT! Fri, Aug 25, 7:15 am - I've got something very serious I'm looking at. Please take note of this if you live around the Galveston area or share this with someone that you know who lives around the Galveston area. They could be facing another Cat 2 or higher hurricane bearing down next week!!! This is NOT fear mongering. I don't do that. This is proactive thinking that could save lives and property. There is so many people talking about Hurricane Harvey on TV and online, my fear is that this message will get drowned out. I don't see many meteorologists talking about what I'm going to outline here and its serious stuff folks. I've been noting since the beginning of the week here on FB that there's a very good possibility that after Harvey makes landfall near Corpus Christi, it will loop back into the Gulf of Mexico, crawl up the coastline, and then make landfall again next week near the Texas-Louisiana border. Now it looks like the second landfall will be slightly Northeast of Galveston (not the TX/LA border) and will come in around Tues or Weds of next week - as a major hurricane AGAIN! I'm talking Cat 2 or higher! Here's the BIG problem: Everyone is focused on

Here's the BIG problem: Everyone is focused on Corpus right now and not thinking about what's likely to occur next week further up the coastline. All of the coastal counties up through TX/LA border need to be thinking about potentially evacuating or preparing for the scenario RIGHT NOW before the flooding starts. If people wait too late with the severe flooding that is projected over the next 2 to 3 days, it could be too hard or too late to get people up and out of the Galveston area if storm does indeed come to the Galveston area as lI'm suggesting. Folks, I honestly hope this doesn't happen, but it looks like there's a very good chance that it will. I'll take the grief if I'm wrong about this, but I'd rather people be prepared, rather than caught in a horrible, life- threatening situation. SAT WED TUE SUN 50 KTS 1 MON- THIS EVE 25

Ok. Hasn't stopped raining since 6pm yesterday. Windy, roads r slick. We only lost power for one hour. So far were good. I'm used to flooding around here. I prepared pretty well. Confident we'll be fine. Good to hear! Keep us updated. Thinking about yall constantly. Yes ma'am! Thank you That's not what I've heard from our local meteorologist. I trust him. It won't happen.

[Fundraiser for our members affected by Hurricane Harvey flooding] On August 26, 2017, Hurricane Harvey devastated the Cities of Houston and Katy, Texas. As a Fire Department, our members banded together to help our community and assist neighborhoods and agencies around us. Many of our members were out in the flood waters across the Katy area helping our community even as they got reports that their own homes were flooding. These men and women, whether paid or volunteers, worked multiple shifts and selflessly served others while their own homes and families were inundated by the most damaging storm to ever hit our area. If you can not give, please share this effort with those you know and let's show these men and women we count on that they can count on us.

Please watch this great piece (video in the article) that members wno were impacted by Hurricane #Harvey and our fundraising campaign to help them repair and rebuild. If you are looking for a way to give money and know that 100% of your funds go directly to families impacted by this historic flooding, the link to our YouCaring fund is in the story below. Houston did about our 16 #KatyStrong

I'm tired. Tired of rain, tired of worrying, tired of not sleeping. But safe!!! And so so grateful that we are dry and were able to help in at least a small way today. Nathan and Clint launched his boat (thanks to Mike Loftin pulling them deep enough with his tractor!) and rescued some friends and their dog. Then Nate went back in and rescued about 25 more people. Love how our community is banding together, and beyond grateful for the volunteers and emergency response crews who are out there assisting people. Big shout out to the and the community. l've now seen firsthand how tired the firefighters are, and never really realized until these last few days just how much their families sacrifice When they're working for days on end on our behalf, their families are home without them, and that sucks. THANKS to the other crews out there!!! : families for their help to and all
